Name: Universal Health Services
Name_1: AJK striving to create universal health care system: Masood Khan
Text_1:
AJK striving to create universal health care system: Masood Khan

Pakistan AJK striving to create universal health care system: Masood Khan

AJK striving to create universal health care system: Masood Khan

12 June2021 11:16 pm

MUZAFFARABAD (Dunya News) - The AJK Sardar Masood Khan visited Midland Doctors Medical Institute (MDMI) located at Tandali along the Muzaffarabad-Srinagar Highway and praised the diagnostic and treatment facilities being provided to the patients there.

Established with the efforts and generous financial support of Pakistani and Kashmiri doctors serving in the United Kingdom after the devastating earthquake of 2005 this state-of-the-art hospital started providing medical facilities in 2013 and has so far provided 367702 patients free medical facilities of international standard.

On arrival at the hospital President Sardar Masood Khan was warmly welcomed by Bilal Hussain Chief Executive Officer of the hospital Ejaz Raza Chaudhry Chairman Red Crescent Society Azad Kashmir eminent Urologist Dr. Naeem Ahmed Butt Dr. Ali Sheikh Dr. Shabnam and members of the hospital staff and management.

The President took a round of various sections of the hospital and was briefed about the facilities for General Surgery Pediatrics Urology Cardiology Dentistry Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology Lab Pharmacy General Medicine and Pediatrics Malnutrition.

He also visited other departments where he was given a detailed briefing on the medical and diagnostic facilities being provided to the patients as well as the modern medical machinery and equipment used in the hospital. Commenting on the occasion the President said that this is a modern hospital where the best facilities are being provided for the treatment of patients suffering from heart disease diabetes and the children with symptoms of malnutrition.

Thanking doctors in the UK and other countries for setting up and running the hospital successfully President Sardar Masood Khan said it was a testament of our expatriates’ love for their motherland and their countrymen.

Khan said that the provision of such huge medical facilities in Muzaffarabad is helping to save hundreds of human lives and it makes us proud to see it as an important addition to the health sector of the region.

The State President said that he was very pleased to see that in addition to the medical equipment and machinery used in the hospital the performance of the staff serving in the hospital was also of international standard.

Speaking on the occasion Chief Executive Officer of the hospital Bilal Hussain and Dr. Naeem said that in addition to the existing facilities in the hospital the Midland doctors medical institute is planning to install Cath-Lab for the cardiology department and it will be the first-ever unit in Muzaffarabad and surroundings.

President Khan was told that in Gynecology Department the hospital is carrying out C-Section/cesarean Hysterectomy (Abdominal and Vaginal) Laparotomies (for Ectopic pregnancy Ovarian masses Cysts) Dilatation and Curettage MVA Pipple Sampling PAP Smears McDonald Stitch Laparoscopies (Diagnostic and operative) Fibroid removal Myomectomy etc.

Similarly in Urology theatre all kind of endoscopic surgeries such as PCNL TURP TURBT URS (DJ-Stunting) Cystoscopy Pyelolithotomy Prostate Vasectomy Orchiopexy Hydrocele Male Circumcision etc are carried out. “In general surgeries we are performing laparoscopic surgeries such as LAP COLI. The procedures such as LITHTHRIPSY and Retrograde Intrarenal stone surgery treatment of kidney stone are available only MDMI in AJK.
Name_2: Deaf Community Mental Health and Barriers to Care
Text_2:
The deaf community struggles daily with stigma prejudice and communication but that's not all: medical studies have found that deaf people suffer from mental health issues at about twice the rate of the general population and also have real problems accessing needed mental health services.

The mental health issues common in the deaf community include depression anxiety and severe illnesses such as bipolar disorder and schizophrenia.

Mental illnesses are compounded in the deaf community by difficulties communicating with care providers — researchers have found that lip-reading isn't adequate interpreters who know sign language are scarce and many diagnostic tools depend on knowledge that's not common among those who are deaf.

Mental Health in the Deaf Community

Lots of people have some hearing loss — between 15% and 26% of the population according to one study. But it's a different issue to be profoundly deaf especially if you became deaf before you had a chance to learn spoken language. About seven in every 10000 people fall into this category and most regard themselves as a cultural minority that uses sign language instead of spoken language.

Struggles to function in a hearing world can lead to mental health issues. In one study involving hearing-impaired individuals some 41% said they believed that communication problems coupled with family stresses and overall prejudice could cause or contribute to suicidal depression substance abuse or violent behavior in some cases.

If your loved one is deaf and having suicidal thoughts contact the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 988 for support and assistance from a trained counselor. If you or a loved one are in immediate danger call 911. For more mental health resources see our National Helpline Database.

Other studies have found that about one-quarter of deaf students have learning difficulties developmental delay visual impairment or autism. Deaf children who have trouble communicating with their families are four times more likely to be affected by mental health disorders than deaf children who have few or no problems communicating with family members.

Bullying of deaf children also may be common at school and deaf boys and girls are much more likely to be victims of sexual assault.

Communication Needed but Scarce

Mental health services are difficult for deaf people to access. One small study involving 54 people found that more than half hadn't been able to find mental health services that they as deaf people could use.

In addition psychiatric conditions such as mood disorders are frequently under-diagnosed in the deaf community in large part due to communication difficulties that include:

few experienced interpreters between English and sign language

problems in translation between spoken and sign language

differences in how deaf people display feelings and perceive mental health

Reading and writing aren't an adequate substitute for spoken language in this context. Hearing loss interferes quite a lot with vocabulary and so many deaf high school graduates read and write at a grade-school level.

In addition lip-reading is far from 100% accurate — the average deaf adult can lip-read only 26% to 40% of speech.

How to Access Mental Health Services

Because of these communication problems the majority of participants in one study of deaf individuals found that the deaf preferred a deaf professional to provide them with mental health services.﻿﻿ In addition experienced interpreters are very important ... but they're only the first step in helping the deaf access adequate mental health services.

Issues with time are important in diagnosing mental disorders — questions such as "Have you experienced difficulty sleeping for one month or more during the past year?" or "for six months or more?" are common. However these concepts are hard to describe in sign language as are phrases such as "feeling on edge."

Finally questions in diagnostic interviews that rely on the knowledge of what it's like to hear pose real difficulties: How does one ask someone who's been deaf his whole life if he has been "hearing voices"?

Differences Important to Recognize

Mental health providers must also learn how to recognize and address the differences in how a deaf individual displays feelings and expressions from those who are hearing.

For example someone who is deaf may pound on the floor to get attention. While this is considered aggressive by those who can hear it is actually quite accepted and normal within the deaf community.

Also while strong emotional displays are pretty much frowned upon in the hearing community members of the deaf community count on the vivid expression of emotion to convey meaning. As a matter of fact one study found that clinicians often labeled rapid signing as a symptom of psychotic behavior rather than the change of mood that was actually indicated.﻿﻿ And there are few signs within sign language that can account for subtle changes in mood.

What Can Be Done to Help the Deaf Community?

A research study of cultural and linguistic barriers to mental health found that many deaf people have a fear of being incorrectly committed because they are unable to communicate with the staff. One participant is quoted as saying "Even if I were just asking for directions at the information desk [of a psychiatric hospital] miscommunication could lead to my being committed mistakenly ... I don't want to go there even for a visit!"

This study further indicated that participants felt professionals erroneously consider a nominal level of communication to be adequate. One practitioner looked at bipolar disorder in patients who had become deaf before they learned to speak and found that those making diagnoses often emphasized appearance over documented symptoms and other information.

While it will be difficult to solve these problems some solutions are possible. Hearing-impaired people should be encouraged to consider careers in the mental health field and mental health professionals should secure more translators to work with the mentally ill.

The National Association of the Deaf notes that deaf people have the right to push for referrals to mental health professionals who have experience working with those who are deaf or are hard of hearing. The organization also says that deaf people have the right to communicate "in the language and mode of communication that is effective for you" and to clearly understand the diagnosis and recommendations for their treatment.

Clinicians who have little or no experience working with the hearing-impaired should use extreme caution and seek second opinions when diagnosing the deaf. In addition research and effort are needed to bridge the language barriers which now make it so difficult to communicate.
Name_3: After the pandemic a wave of spending by older consumers
Text_3:
(BLOOMBERG) - The world's emergence from the coronavirus pandemic is set to unleash a wave of spending by older consumers with increasing opportunities for investors in ageing-linked stocks.

That's the view of money managers who see huge pent-up demand from wealthy seniors for medical services and luxury goods. They also expect that the forced adoption of the Internet by older people during lockdown will open up this demographic permanently to e-commerce companies and social networks.

The number of people aged 65 and over is projected to double to more 1.5 billion by 2050 greatly increasing their economic impact. The total spending power of the older population globally was about US$8.4 trillion (S$11.1 trillion) in 2020 according to World Data Lab. That's expected to grow to US$14 trillion over the next decade.

"The pandemic has accelerated many of the issues related to aging populations and has highlighted the urgency of resolving them" said Mr Christopher Rossbach chief investment officer at J. Stern. "We think they will be significant drivers for growth and investment."

Underpinning the thesis are global fertility rates that are forecast to keep falling as life expectancy rises even as the virus takes a staggering human toll. China's decision in May to allow three-child families may have only limited impact on the ageing trend in the most populous country.

Here are some key focuses of investors who argue that the ageing theme will be even more important as economies move past the pandemic.

Pent-up medical demand

From cancer screening to hip replacements and cataract surgery countless medical procedures have been postponed since the virus took hold. As this changes global healthcare spending is projected to bounce back in 2021 rising 5.8 per cent to US$8.8 trillion according to IHS Markit.

Mr Rossbach expects shares of medical device manufacturers to benefit and cited Thermo Fisher Scientific Medtronic Becton Dickinson and Alcon.

Shares of all four companies have underperformed the global stock benchmark so far this year.

Mirabaud Asset Management also likes Medtronic as well as Edwards Lifesciences for exposure to the cardiovascular diseases sector said global equities head Anu Narula.

Hearing aids are another market hurt by fewer in-person consultations with Morgan Stanley estimating sales will normalise this year following a 15 per cent decline in the market in 2020. Among businesses in this field it has an overweight recommendation on Copenhagen-listed GN Store Nord and equal-weight on Demant which have both surged this year.

"The large contingent of developed countries that have universal health coverage is being joined by an increasing number of developing markets that are establishing and/or expanding universal health-care systems especially in emerging Asian markets" said Mirabaud's Mr Narula.

Yearning for luxury and travel

As well as long-delayed holidays the travel sector is poised to pick up with support from cashed-up seniors. "Older or richer people tend to want to visit relatives more" said Mr Sanjiv Bhatia founder of Pembroke Emerging Markets.

Mr Rossbach also has his eye on a rebound in luxury spending with LVMH and liquor makers Pernod Ricard and Diageo among his preferred reopening bets.

"A general point is that as people age their purchasing power increases and they become more concerned with quality not quantity of their consumption" he said.

Name: Ventas
Name_1: Palacio Arzobispal y Seminario Conciliar: las problemáticas ventas de nuestro patrimonio nacional
Text_1: El Palacio Arzobispal de San Juan sede -desde el siglo XVIII- de la máxima autoridad de la Iglesia Católica en Puerto Rico y el edificio aledaño construido como seminario a principios del XIX son dos de los edificios más hermosos y emblemáticos de la ciudad de San Juan que este año celebra los quinientos años de su traslado a la isleta donde se encuentra. Constituyen parte de un patrimonio edificado que da fe de la trayectoria de nuestro pueblo a lo largo de los siglos. El conjunto urbano de calles iglesias plazas paseos monumentos fuertes y edificios públicos representa nuestra cultura nuestra manera particular de vivir en sociedad.
Name_2: La camiseta especial de Victoria Beckham por el Orgullo que arrasa en ventas
Text_2:
Victoria Beckham lleva un tiempo luchando por reflotar su firma de moda y conseguir ese ansiado éxito que aún se le resiste en esta industria. En los últimos días la diseñadora inglesa ha decidido lanzar una camiseta con motivo del mes del Orgullo Gay y está siendo todo un éxito en ventas y es que para la ocasión ha conseguido la colaboración del grupo con el que saltó a la fama cuando todavía era cantante: las 'Spice Girls'.

Un proyecto muy especial y exitoso

La esposa de David Beckham se ha convertido en los últimos días en una de las principales personalidades que han decidido mostrar su apoyo públicamente en la lucha contra la homofobia algo que desde siempre ha respaldado pero que en este mes se acentúa. Por ello ha pensado que no podría hacerlo de mejor manera que lanzando una camiseta de edición limitada que está arrasando en ventas y con la que espera obtener ese impulso tan necesario para remediar la difícil situación económica que atraviesa su negocio.

Para la elaboración de la prenda ha colaborado no sólo con las 'Spice Girls' sino también con Albert Kennedy Trust llevando uno de los éxitos más icónicos del grupo como principal lema de la camiseta. El próximo mes de julio se cumplirán 25 años del exitoso 'Wannabe' por lo que esta camiseta lleva el lema 'Proud and wannabe your lover'; un juego de palabras que está encantando a sus seguidores.

Por supuesto la recaudación de su venta irá destinada a Albert Kennedy Trust para que siga financiando la lcuha contra la falta de vivienda para jóvenes LGTBQ+ en el Reino Unido. La camiseta puede adquirirse a través de su página web por el precio de 90 euros aunque ya se han agotado las tallas más grandes. "Estoy muy orgullosa de apoyar el Pride 2021" escribió la propia Victoria Beckham compartiendo el diseño en los últimos días en sus redes sociales. Como viene siendo habitual también David Beckham y sus hijso se han sumado a esta iniciativa.

Name_4: Ventas de discos de vinilo se disparan durante pandemia
Text_4:
Las ventas de discos de vinilo se dispararon durante la pandemia de coronavirus mientras los amantes de la música ampliaban sus colecciones y los casetes de audio también iniciaron su regreso impulsando los negocios de las tiendas de discos.

La reducción de las restricciones por el virus en los establecimientos y el continuo interés en los discos de vinilo les dieron a las tiendas y a los compradores un motivo para celebrar el sábado en la primera de dos fechas del Record Store Day.

Aunque muchas tiendas estuvieron cerradas al inicio de la pandemia de coronavirus la gente escuchaba discos en casa e impulsó las ventas de discos de vinilo por internet y para recogerlos en las tiendas.

Will Emanuel un estudiante de la Universidad de Maine que permaneció en su casa a las afueras de Portland compró entre 50 y 55 álbumes durante la pandemia. “Estaba ansioso de crear una colección” dijo Emanuel. “Caí en la trampa y ahora parece que no puedo salir”.

Emanuel de 20 años es parte de una nueva generación que se siente atraída al sonido cálido la carátula y al ambiente retro de los discos de vinilo uniéndose a otros estadounidenses que crecieron con el formato para aumentar las ventas.

Las ventas de discos de vinilo subieron un 29% en el 2020 a US$ 626 millones superando el ingreso de ventas de los discos compactos de acuerdo con la Asociación de la Industria Discográfica de Estados Unidos.

Los casetes de audio también están experimentando un renovado interés aunque siguen siendo una novedad en lo que respeta a las ventas totales gracias a la ayuda que han recibido de Hollywood y Netflix.

En la película de Marvel “Guardianes de la Galaxia” aparece un casete con los éxitos de la década de 1960 y de 1970 que se convirtió en un éxito de ventas mientras que en la serie “Stranger Things” de Netflix se muestra una cinta con canciones de The Clash y otros artistas de la década de 1980.

Este renovado interés por los discos de vinilo y casetes es un buen augurio para la celebración anual de las tiendas de música indie esos centros musicales locales donde la gente puede buscar discos CD y casetes y hablar de música.
Name_5: Caen ventas en puestos de café 80% en La Paz
Text_5:
La Paz Baja California Sur (OEM-Informex).- Caen las ventas hasta en un 80% en algunos de los negocios de café en la ciudad de La Paz. Tras 3 años en el negocio de café la señora Cristina Geraldo aseguró que la pandemia a afectado gravemente a estos negocios. Además de mencionar que ante la falta de clases presenciales y el cierre de las mismas en guarderías kínderes primarias y secundarias en los niveles más básicos de la educación los clientes han bajado notablementeasí como las ventas.

La señora Cristina Geraldo dueña de un café ubicado en la calle Licenciado Primo Verdad y calle Oaxaca señalo que la llegada de la pandemia ha afectado a muchos negocios de café quienes han bajado sus ventas de manera notoria sufriendo las consecuencias en una economía debilitada y vulnerable.

“En estos 3 años del café lo más difícil ha sido la llegada de la pandemia la cual nos tomo de sorpresa. Prácticamente no había venta los clientes no venían por el mismo miedo a los contagios y un pánico impresionante por tantas noticias tan feas que salían en los medios que nos llegaban a nuestro celular”.

Municipios ¡Llega el calor! suben ventas en hieleras de La Paz

“La verdad es que o no teníamos ventas al día o solamente vendíamos a lo mucho de un 10% a un 20% lo cual era una situación muy difícil de superar. Además nuestros clientes más frecuentes eran los de las escuelas los padres y madres de familias esto nos pego mucho al negocio porque ya no venían por el lonche porque cerraron las escuelas”.

Actualmente aseguró que las ventas bajaron en un 80% además tuvieron que cerrar por un mes y medio el negocio de café debido a que en la familia les dio esta enfermedad provocada por el virus del Covid-19 por lo cual se vieron obligados a cerrar el negocio y hacer cuarentena en el mismo hogar sin salir a ninguna parte.

“En la familia tuvimos el contagio por el Covid-19 estuvimos un mes y medio sin abrir el negocio afortunadamente pudimos superar esta enfermedad porque no nos pego tan fuerte tampoco tuvimos ningún fallecimiento en la familia una vez recuperados volvimos a abrir siguiendo todas las medidas e indicaciones de salud”.

“Ya se ve un poco mas de movimiento mucha gente tiene que ir a trabajar nos estamos recuperando un poquito pero todavía nos falta mucho para recuperarnos en las ventas. Lo bueno es que no pago renta porque aquí vivo esto me ayudo un poco a no cerrar porque en realidad muchas personas que rentaban tuvieron que cerrar por lo mismo”.

Suscríbete aquí a la edición digital de El Sudcaliforniano

La mayor venta es de café avena burritos empanadas y sándwiches. El horario es de 6 de la mañana a 12 y media del día de lunes a sábados. Muchos de estos negocios han desaparecido al tener que pagar renta y simplemente no tener ingresos para cubrir el monto de la renta debemos de apoyar lo más posible a los negocios locales familiares para que no tengan que cerrar sus puertas y seguirnos cuidando por el tema de la pandemia.

Name_2: Samsung Galaxy S9 is Old and Still Getting Fresh Updates With Improvements
Text_2:
The Samsung Galaxy S9 may have dropped back to the quarterly update schedule as it finds itself in a final year of support but that still means regular updates. The latest update has arrived this week through Verizon with a fresh-ish security patch and some improvements.

If you haven’t seen it already the Galaxy S9 and Galaxy S9+ on Verizon are receiving software versions QP1A.190711.020.G960USQU9FUE1 and QP1A.190711.020.G965USQU9FUE1. This update includes the May Android security patch as well as the new Quick Share enhancements other Samsung devices have seen and “performance improvements.” Samsung and Verizon aren’t being specific on what changes but hey a 3-year old phone seeing improvements is a good thing.

The Galaxy S9 should continue to see these quarterly updates until next April or so when Samsung will then fully cut it off. At that time this phone from March 2018 will have seen 4 years of updates.

To check for the update head into Settings>System updates>Check for system updates.

Name_5: $15-A-Month Internet Law on Hold in New York Judge Rules
Text_5:
What to Know New York cannot require internet providers to offer broadband service for low-income customers for as little as $15-a-month starting next week a federal judge ruled

The low-income broadband consumers law passed in the state budget in April which was supposed to come into effect on Tuesday

The judge said the internet providers have shown that they could suffer “imminent irreparable injury” because of the law's potential impact on their wallets

New York cannot require internet providers to offer broadband service for low-income customers for as little as $15-a-month starting next week a federal judge ruled on Friday.

The low-income broadband consumers law passed in the state budget in April which was supposed to come into effect on Tuesday. It allowed the state’s attorney general to issue penalties up to $1000 per violation from providers.

USTelecom CTIA the New York State Telecommunications Association and other industry groups representing internet providers had sued in April arguing that the law meant they could either face penalties for not complying or be forced to provide the services “at a loss.”

Get Tri-state area news and weather forecasts to your inbox. Sign up for NBC New York newsletters.

U.S. District Court Senior District Judge Denis R. Hurley of the Eastern District of New York said in a preliminary injunction "the internet's promise of access" hinges on whether people can afford it.

But the judge said the internet providers have shown that they could suffer “imminent irreparable injury” because of the law's potential impact on their wallets. Three of the internet companies told the court that the law would reduce annual net income by at least $1 million each.

“While a telecommunications giant like Verizon may be able to absorb such a loss others may not” the judge wrote. “The Champlain Telephone Company for example ‘estimates that nearly half of its existing broadband customers will quality for discounted rates’ with each customer ‘causing a monetary loss.’”

The law also requires providers to advertise the broadband plan for low-income consumers. Verizon estimated the ad campaign would cost between $250000 and $1 million.

New York state argued those estimates aren't backed by any financial records.

But Judge Hurley said that state didn't cite any reason that the courts shouldn't rely on the internet companies' financial estimates which they submitted under penalty of perjury.

The judge questioned whether a state can tell an internet provider how much they can charge consumers. Internet providers have argued they are primarily subject to federal law which regulates interstate commerce.

In February a federal judge's ruling cleared the way for the state of California to ban internet providers from slowing down or blocking access to websites and applications that don’t pay for premium service.

But Judge Hurley pointed out that California's attorney general had argued that the state's law did “'not regulate how much providers can charge their customers.'”

The judge also noted that low-income individuals can now ask for $50 off their monthly bill under a new temporary federal benefit.

Gov. Andrew Cuomo spokesperson Rich Azzopardi said that New York will keep defending the law.

“We always knew big telecom would pull out all the stops to protect their profits at the expense of the New Yorkers who need access to this vital utility the most" Azzopardi said in a Friday statement. "We are going to continue to fight for them.”

Name: Visa Inc
Name_1: Princess Diana Was "Visibly Blushing" While Dancing with Neil Diamond at the White House Photographer Says
Text_1:
Princess Diana made an impression during her 1985 visit to the White House.

The late royal attended a dinner hosted by then-President Ronald Reagan and First Lady Nancy Reagan at which she danced with famous men like actor John Travolta and singer Neil Diamond.

Recently Travolta opened up about dancing with the Princess of Wales in an interview with Esquire Mexico describing the experience as a "fairytale" and a "magical moment."

"Think of the setting. We were at the White House. It's midnight. The stage is like a dream. I approach her touch her elbow invite her to dance" he explained. "She spins around and gives me that captivating smile just a little sad and accepts my invitation. And there we were dancing together as if it were a fairytale. Who could ever imagine something like that would happen to them someday? I was smart enough to stamp it in my memory as a very special magical moment."

Photo credit: Anwar Hussein - Getty Images

In April former White House photographer Pete Souza shared his own memory from Diana's visit to the Capitol—specifically her dance with Diamond.

⁣

"After posting my photograph of Diana and John Travolta yesterday many of you had asked to see a picture of her dancing with Neil Diamond" Souza wrote on Instagram along with a photo of the moment. "Accompanied by the military band Neil sang a few of his songs. I distinctly remember him singing 'You Don’t Bring Me Flowers.' My recollection–and I can’t be sure this is correct–is that he continued singing this song as he danced with her.⁣ The one rock-solid remembrance I have is that Diana was visibly blushing when she danced with Neil. In the photograph you can see that her cheeks are a bit red but in the moment it was even more obvious.⁣"

Name_2: Nigerian mobile payments company Paga may be Africa’s next Unicorn plans expansion to Mexico and Ethiopia
Text_2:
Attaining the Tech Unicorn status in Africa is slowly becoming mainstream. There have been two African unicorns this year Flutterwave and Chippercash with valuations of over $1billion. And now Paga the free mobile application that enables users to conduct free financial transactions such as making payments sending and receiving money is gunning to become Africa’s biggest unicorn

Founded in 2009 by Tayo Oviosu the company processed $2.3 billion worth of transactions in 2020 and $8 billion during the past four years. It has 17 million unique users including tech entrepreneurs businesses and individuals in Africa’s most populous nation.

Paga has over 27000 agents across the country who perform similar roles like bank tellers with many retail outlets where consumers can access services like bill payments and other types of transactions.

Paga is also making its programming interface available to tech entrepreneurs for payments while expanding its consumer business through the partnership with Visa.

In a tweet made by Tayo the company crossed N3 trillion in transaction values processed since the company started operations in 2012. They reached N2 trillion in March 2020 and N3 trillion in May 2021.

The company has top investors like U.S. billionaire investor Tim Draper and former Goldman Sachs Group Inc. economist Jim O’Neil. Tayo in an interview with Bloomberg said that Paga could reach a valuation of at least $1 billion “in the next year or two.”

The company is looking to expand into Ethiopia and Mexico where it could also facilitate payments for the millions who lack access to banking services. Expansion into Ethiopia Africa’s second-most populous nation is set for next year.

To foster its expansion plans the company is counting on its deal with Visa Inc. The agreement will provide merchant solutions in Nigeria from this month allowing payments by money transfer and a QR code among others.
Name_3: Fifth Most Popular Among Hedge Funds Beats The Market
Text_3:
In this article we will check out the progression of hedge fund sentiment towards Visa Inc (NYSE:V) and determine whether it is a good investment right now. We at Insider Monkey like to examine what billionaires and hedge funds think of a company before spending days of research on it. Given their 2 and 20 payment structure hedge funds have more incentives and resources than the average investor. The funds have access to expert networks and get tips from industry insiders. They also employ numerous Ivy League graduates and MBAs. Like everyone else hedge funds perform miserably at times but their consensus picks have historically outperformed the market after risk adjustments.

Visa Inc (NYSE:V) has seen a decrease in support from the world’s most elite money managers recently. Visa Inc (NYSE:V) was in 164 hedge funds’ portfolios at the end of March. The all time high for this statistic is 166. There were 166 hedge funds in our database with V holdings at the end of December. Our calculations also showed that Visa ranked 5th among the 30 most popular stocks among hedge funds (click for Q1 rankings).

Hedge funds’ reputation as shrewd investors has been tarnished in the last decade as their hedged returns couldn’t keep up with the unhedged returns of the market indices. Our research has shown that hedge funds’ small-cap stock picks managed to beat the market by double digits annually between 1999 and 2016 but the margin of outperformance has been declining in recent years. Nevertheless we were still able to identify in advance a select group of hedge fund holdings that outperformed the S&P 500 ETFs by 115 percentage points since March 2017 (see the details here). We were also able to identify in advance a select group of hedge fund holdings that underperformed the market by 10 percentage points annually between 2006 and 2017. Interestingly the margin of underperformance of these stocks has been increasing in recent years. Investors who are long the market and short these stocks would have returned more than 27% annually between 2015 and 2017. We have been tracking and sharing the list of these stocks since February 2017 in our quarterly newsletter.

At Insider Monkey we leave no stone unturned when looking for the next great investment idea. For example advertising technology one of the fastest growing industries right now so we are checking out stock pitches like this under-the-radar adtech stock that can deliver 10x gains. We go through lists like the 10 best hydrogen fuel cell stocks to pick the next Tesla that will deliver a 10x return. Even though we recommend positions in only a tiny fraction of the companies we analyze we check out as many stocks as we can. We read hedge fund investor letters and listen to stock pitches at hedge fund conferences. You can subscribe to our free daily newsletter on our homepage. Keeping this in mind we’re going to take a look at the recent hedge fund action encompassing Visa Inc (NYSE:V).

Do Hedge Funds Think V Is A Good Stock To Buy Now?

At first quarter’s end a total of 164 of the hedge funds tracked by Insider Monkey were bullish on this stock a change of -1% from the fourth quarter of 2020. Below you can check out the change in hedge fund sentiment towards V over the last 23 quarters. So let’s see which hedge funds were among the top holders of the stock and which hedge funds were making big moves.

Among these funds Fisher Asset Management held the most valuable stake in Visa Inc (NYSE:V) which was worth $4840.2 million at the end of the fourth quarter. On the second spot was TCI Fund Management which amassed $2976.5 million worth of shares. Berkshire Hathaway Fundsmith LLP and Akre Capital Management were also very fond of the stock becoming one of the largest hedge fund holders of the company. In terms of the portfolio weights assigned to each position Truvvo Partners allocated the biggest weight to Visa Inc (NYSE:V) around 33.17% of its 13F portfolio. Hengistbury Investment Partners is also relatively very bullish on the stock designating 23.42 percent of its 13F equity portfolio to V.

Due to the fact that Visa Inc (NYSE:V) has faced declining sentiment from the entirety of the hedge funds we track logic holds that there was a specific group of money managers that elected to cut their full holdings heading into Q2. Intriguingly Marcio Appel’s Adam Capital dropped the biggest stake of the 750 funds tracked by Insider Monkey valued at about $35.4 million in stock. Mendel Hui’s fund Isomer Partners also dumped its stock about $32.8 million worth. These bearish behaviors are important to note as aggregate hedge fund interest fell by 2 funds heading into Q2.

Let’s go over hedge fund activity in other stocks – not necessarily in the same industry as Visa Inc (NYSE:V) but similarly valued. These stocks are Johnson & Johnson (NYSE:JNJ) Walmart Inc. (NYSE:WMT) Mastercard Incorporated (NYSE:MA) UnitedHealth Group Inc. (NYSE:UNH) The Walt Disney Company (NYSE:DIS) Bank of America Corporation (NYSE:BAC) and The Procter & Gamble Company (NYSE:PG). Name_4: How Much AI Talent Gets Paid at Snowflake Databricks UiPath and More
Text_4:
Few industries are blowing up like artificial intelligence and big data. A combination of new technology and expanding adoption are sparking meteoric growth. The analyst firm PitchBook estimates spending on AI software and hardware will reach $138 billion this year and grow at a rate of 23% in the next three years. That puts the industry at $258 billion in 2024.

This story is available exclusively to Business Insider subscribers. Become an Insider and start reading now.

All that spending fuels an equally explosive jobs market. The job search site ZipRecruiter shows 48955 artificial intelligence engineer jobs currently listed in the US. Those jobs pay very very well. ZipRecruiter shows annual salaries as high as $304500 for AI engineers with an average of $164769. There are also AI job openings for researchers human resources workers and managers.

PitchBook notes that "the size of this market can support both large private companies as well as meaningful growth opportunities for large enterprises." Insider previously listed salaries for some of those larger enterprises including IBM Microsoft and Oracle. Now we turn to those large startups and younger public companies which are providing a new employment sector with a central focus on AI.

Business Insider analyzed the US Office of Foreign Labor Certification's disclosure data from the beginning of 2021 through the end of March for permanent and temporary foreign workers to find out what 10 top AI companies — Snowflake UiPath Databricks DataRobot Samsara ByteDance Cruise Waymo Dataminr and OpenAI — pay engineers researchers and other professionals in the field of big data AI and machine learning.

Companies are required to disclose information such as salary ranges when they hire through the H-1B visa program. This list is not a comprehensive look at AI salaries: It only includes data for foreign workers and only accounts for base salary rather than bonuses benefits or other forms of compensation. However it still provides rare insight into what these major companies are willing to shell out for talent. Note that for some positions the companies involved only gave salary ranges rather than specific figures.

Name_5: Jamaican workers allegedly scammed by US hospitality companies | Loop Jamaica
Text_5:
Three officials linked to several hospitality companies in Myrtle Beach South Carolina in the United States have been charged with several offences in relation to a scam which led to dozen of foreign workers including Jamaicans being lied to about their pay and work conditions.

Raja Younas Syed Naqvi and Jessica Voight who all work for tourism and hospitality-related companies in Myrtle Beach are accused of lying to get non-immigrants to the US for work.

The trio have been charged with conspiracy to commit wire fraud money laundering and visa fraud according to the US Attorney's Office for the District of South Carolina in a news release on Thursday.

Many of the victims are from Jamaica and the Philippines but there are other victims from other countries officials further disclosed.

The authorities have already identified several of the victims.

The indictment alleged that Younas who is a registered agent president and chief executive of Grandeur Management Inc; Naqvi the registered agent and organiser of Rida Naqvi LLC; Voight an employee of Grandeur Management and other hospitality businesses "devised a scheme to defraud workers outside the United States to work for the defendants”.

It is alleged that the conspirators not only submitted false and fraudulent visa petitions but also misrepresented the positions duties rates of pay working conditions and living conditions to collect unauthorised and improper fees from aliens seeking H-2B non-immigrant visas.

According to the indictment the conspirators would use separate accounts in order to pay employees differently based on their current non-immigration or alien status in the United States.

It is also alleged that despite promising the workers full-time work the conspirators provided less than full-time work and consistently paid the workers less than the amounts that are stated in the workers’ contracts and in the applications the defendants submitted to the United States Department of Labour and the US Citizenship and Immigration Services.

The grand fraudulent scheme allegedly plotted by the hospitality companies also involved the conspirators maintaining "an established international cultural exchange programme designed on the whole to exhibit or explain the attitude customs history heritage philosophy traditions and/or other cultural attributes (arts literature language) of the participant’s country of nationality in order to obtain authorisation to sponsor Q-1 visas" the US Attorney's Office disclosed.

But these arrangements never occurred.

Instead "once the non-immigrant employees arrived in the United States they were placed by their visa sponsors into inward-facing housekeeping jobs with no real opportunities for cultural exchange" the statement said.

According to the authorities Younas and Naqvi charged unlawful fees to visa seekers who wired money which the alleged scammers then pocketed among other things.

For her part Voight and others allegedly conducted interviews with the alien workers over the Internet and instructed them on how to wire unlawful visa fees charged by the conspirators and subsequently collected the unlawful fees.

Each of the three accused persons faces up to 20 years in prison on all the charges.

The accused were arraigned in federal court on Thursday and entered not guilty pleas to the charges.

The case was investigated by special agents of the US Department of State’s Diplomatic Security Service (DSS) and the Myrtle Beach Police Department.

Meanwhile the US authorities are appealing to those who were victimised by the defendants’ alleged scheme to contact traffickingtips@state.gov

Name: Berkley
Name_1: Berkley basketball courts dedicated in memory of boys who died in crash
Text_1:
Michael J. DeCicco

Correspondent

BERKLEY— The Crosby-Couto Memorial Basketball Court on the town common was already a success before its grand opening ceremony on June 12.

Crosby-Couto Basketball Foundation member Kim Robidoux said people started playing on the twin courts — built in memory of two Somerset Berkley Regional High School graduates who died in a car crash in March 2020 — as soon as the four hoops were installed on March 20. But the meaning behind this new construction only became obvious when the basketball coaches of the late Devyn Crosby 18 and late Christian Couto 19 retired their jersey numbers and handed them framed to their parents as the ceremony began.

That's when Devyn's mom Lisa Crosby and Christian's mom Tania Couto both had tears in their eyes — as did many people in the crowd — as the ceremony worked its way to conclude with a rendition of "Star Spangled Banner" sung by Emily Nawocki Devyn and Christian's Berkley schools classmate and now a student at the Berklee School of Music.

Soon after the two young men died the Crosby-Couto Basketball Foundation formed to memorialize the pair best friends who both were passionate about playing basketball by refurbishing the town common courts in their name. The Go-Fund Me page that the group began last June raised over $50000 and organizers fashioned plans that included enlarging and resurfacing the existing courts and adding benches safety fencing and most importantly of all plaques engraved with their names on a stone memorial at the head of the courts.

More:Memorial basketball courts for Berkley teens could be up and running by winter

More:Loved ones say memorial basketball courts are fitting tribute to Berkley teens

The grand opening happened right on schedule. Workers finished painting the court last Thursday Robidoux said. All that's left to do she said is to install the fence that will separate the two courts. The work she said was accomplished entirely with private funds and donations and materials that were either donated or bought at lower cost.

Tania Couto who was there with Christian's father Jeff Couto and 14-year-old sister Alexandria said she was amazed by the large turnout for the opening ceremony. "I'd like to thank all those who participated in making this court happen" she said. "This is a great opportunity to remember them the way they should be remembered."

She said she knew just what her son would do if he were here for the ceremony. "He'd be astonished" she said. "He'd be smiling from ear to ear right now."

Lisa Crosby who was there with Devyn's father Bruce Crosby and sister Brianna 22 said she was "relieved" to see the effort to create the memorial court come to a successful conclusion. "It's amazing" she said. "It's wonderful. He (Devyn) would be very pleased."

The ceremony included a blessing of the courts by Father Jason Brilhante of St. John of God's Church in Somerset. Another former classmate of Devyn and Christian Jared Painten announced he was organizing a "three-on-three" basketball tournament to follow the ceremony with entry fees going toward the court's maintenance fund. Painten said 69 players had signed up for this tournament and $690 had been raised — and that's not counting the proceeds expected from raffle tickets and popcorn sales.

Following the tournament he had planned a half-court raffle contest: One basketball shoot for $1; five for $3. Painten said he has played on the new court prior to June 12. "It's the nicest court of any in any surrounding town" he said. "It's a beautiful court to remember them by (Devyn and Christian). I grew up with them. We're all blessed to know they've been a part of our lives."

Name_3: Old Rochester boys and girls win SCC championship track meet titles
Text_3:
Standard-Times

The Old Rochester boys and girls track teams ran away with the South Coast Conference championship meet titles on Saturday at GNB Voc-Tech.

The boys won with 84 points finishing in front of Dighton-Rehoboth (76) Somerset Berkley (69) Apponequet (67) and Fairhaven (62).

The girls won with 150 points finishing in front of Somerset Berkley (84) Dighton-Rehoboth (75) Seekonk (49) and Apponequet (48).

The ORR girls were led by triple winner Jen Williams who took first in the 100 hurdles (15.27) high jump (tied for first with a school-record 5-4) and long jump (16-6).

Julia Sheridan was a double winner in the 400 (1:00.02) and javelin (98-11) while Emma Carroll was first in the 800 (2:28.14) second in the mile (5:32.69) and fifth in the high jump (4-8).

Maggie Brogioli tied Williams for first in the high jump (school-record 5-4) and was second to her in the 100 hurdles (16.17) and long jump (16-5-50). The Bulldogs also got top finishes from Anna Dube in the 800 (2:32.51) Jillian LeBlanc in the 400 hurdles (second; 1:19.06) Cameran Weaver in the triple jump (31-11) and Taylor Green in the shot put (fourth; 27-1.25) and javelin (second; 93-4). Corinne Robert was fourth in 2-mile in 13:59.56 and sixth in discus with 66-10.

ORR also won the 4x400 (4:35.7) with Weaver Aubrey Heis Payton Lord and Dube.

For Apponequet Maggie Gallager won the 2-mile (13:12.17) and took second in the 800 (2:30.05) while Morgan Hayward won the mile (5:31.48) and was second in the 400 (1:01.22) and Emma Marra was fourth in the 200 (21.72).

Fairhaven got top finishes from Tenley Dakin in the 100 (second; 13.56) 200 (third; 27.62) and triple jump (sixth; 30-2) Laura Hubert in the triple jump (fourth; 31-1) Kate Brown in the 2-mile (second; 13:63) and Sophia Medeiros in the mile (fifth; 6:04.40).

Wareham’s Madison Conner was third in the mile (5:56.54) and GNB Voc-Tech’s Cynthia Khorn was third in the 100 hurdles (17.58).

On the boys side ORR’s David Reynolds won the shot put (48-4.25) and discus (135-5) while Colby Gross was first in the 400 (50.99). Leo Schiappa was second in both 100 (11.54) and 200 (23.67).

The Bulldogs also got top finishes from Jackson Veugen in the 2-mile (third; 10:58.11) Jon Perreira in the mile (4:56.03) Matt Curry in the 800 (2:14.00) and Sam Balsis in the 800 (sixth; 2:14.57) Murray Copps in the mile (5:00.70 Will Correia in the 110 hurdles (sixth; 23.76).

GNB Voc-Tech’s Alex DaCruz won the long jump (21-3) and triple jump (44-1) while teammates Daniel Ward won the 400 hurdles (1:01.99) and was second in the 400 (54.00) and Dom Borden took second in the 400 (52.13).

For Apponequet Jackson Gagnier won the javelin (160-0) and was third in the 400 hurdles (1:03.41). The Lakers also got top finishes from Aydan Fournier in the mile (4:54.55) Kalvin Saade in the long jump (second; 18-11.5) Tyler Desrosiers in the long jump (third; 18-10) and Aiden Lehane in the 100 (fifth; 12.13) 200 (third; 24.50) and long jump (fourth; 18-8).

Wareham was led by Kevin DeCollibus and Ryker King. DeCollibus won the 200 (23.60) and was third in the 100 (11.63) while King won the 110 hurdles (16.83) and was fifth in the high jump (5-4). The Vikings also got top performances from Luke Wiley in the 800 (third; 2:13.53) Ben Brogioli in the triple jump (second; 38-7.75)and Garrett Goodman in the discus (second; 119-2).

Fairhaven got wins from Ben Davignon in the mile (4:49.79) Will Benoit in the 800 (2:05.66) Sean Brown in the 2-mile (10:29.42) as well as the 4x800 (9:03.3) team of Davignon Benoit Jarrod Ledvina and Brown. Also placing in events for the Blue Devils were Nate Spellman in the high jump (second; 6-2) Ryan Hartman in the javelin (third; 133-6) Jarrod Ledvina in the 2-mile (fourth; 11:05.23) and Luke Morrison in the 110 hurdles (fifth; 21.75).
Name_4: Greater Fall River track and field athletes compete at championship meets
Text_4:
The Herald News

FALL RIVER — It was championship day for Greater Fall River track and field athletes on Saturday.

Several teams competed in their various league meets.

One of the big stories of the day came from Case’s Jordan Rodrigues who broke his school record in the high jump in the South Coast Conference championships at Greater New Bedford High School. Durfee’s relay teams stormed to three first-place finishes at the Southeast Conference championships

Here’s a look at the results:

BOYS TRACK

CASE

The Cardinals’ Jordan Rodrigues could not compete at the SCC championships last season due to COVID-19. Given another chance in 2021 Rodrigues wasted little time to show how much he missed competing at Saturday’s SCC championship at Greater New Bedford Vocational Technical School.

Rodrigues broke the school record he established two seasons ago in the high jump with a leaped of 6’4”. His previous best was 6’2”.

DURFEE

The Hilltoppers received some great performances at the SEC championships at B.M.C. Durfee High School.

Joe Uwanagho was named champion in the discus event (138-8) and was second in the shot put (43-10).

Jonell Manlove took third in the 100 and fourth in the long jump. Benjamin Hankerson finished in third place in the triple jump.

SOMERSET BERKLEY

The Raiders placed third with 69 points During Saturday’s SCC championship meet at Greater New Bedford Vocational Technical School.

Ian Sullivan placed second in the 110 hurdles and seventh in the 400 hurdles for SB. Cameron Cunningham took second in the javelin and third in the shot put.

Aidan Montag placed second in the 2-mile. Davis Sullivan placed third overall in the 400 while Matt Moreau came in fourth in the 100.

The Raiders took second in the 4x100 and 4x800 relay races.

Diman 98

Bishop Connolly 29

Diman 71

Tri-County 47

The Bengals remain unbeaten after beating Bishop Connolly and Tri-County in their season finale.

Jacob Chouinard was a triple winner for Diman (6-0) winning the 400 hurdles the triple jump and the 200. Jordan Cordeiro was a double winner in the 110 hurdles and high jump. Pete Mayers won the 100 and James Vacanti took first in the 400.

GIRLS TRACK

DURFEE

The Lady Hilltoppers took third place overall with a point total of 73 during the SEC championships at B.M.C. Durfee High School.

Brockton was the top point-getter with 101 followed by Dartmouth with 96.

Durfee won all relay races during the event.

The 4x100 relay team of Shakira Cadet Emma McDonnell Deanalis Donato and Julia Matos finished in first place. The 4x400 relay team of Kyla Lockhart Julia Hardgraves Julia Raposa and Abigale Long took first place.

The 4x800 relay team of Louraine Dayo Meadow Worsley Maggie O'Connell and Camryn Letendre completed the sweep with a first-place finish.

Donato broke the school record in the 100 with a first-place time of 12.7. Alisha Gonzales took first in the discus and fourth in the shot put.

Other top performers were Cadet (second and school record; 400) and (fourth; triple jump) Letendre (fifth; mile) Long (fourth; high jump) Malin Mayo (fifth; javelin) McDonnell (third; long jump) and (third; 100) O'Connell (second; 2-mile) and Raposa (third; 400 hurdles).

SOMERSET BERKLEY

The Lady Raiders placed second with 84 points at the SCC championship meet at Greater New Bedford Vocational Technical School.

Elena Cabral was the champion in the 100 while placing second in the 200 and triple jump. Other top individual performers were Corryn Fisher (third; long jump) and (fourth; 100 hurdles) Marissa Medeiros (second; 400 hurdles) Nicole Ledwidge (third; 2-mile) Cami Crook (fourth; mile) and McKenzie Offley (sixth; high jump).

The 4x800 relay team of Lauren Rothwell Gabriella Fernandes Ledwidge and Crook placed first. The 4x100 team took second place.

Diman 100

Bishop Connolly 29

Diman 84

Tri-County 48

The Lady Bengals swept their meet against Bishop Connolly and Tri-County in their season finale.

Inez Medeiros was a double winner for Diman (5-1) in the 100 and 200. Emily Gonzales also won two events in the 100 hurdles and 400 hurdles. Sarai Benitez won the 400 and placed second in the 100.

BASEBALL

Bishop Connolly 6

Atlantis Charter 5

The Cougars came from behind to beat Atlantis Charter.

Connor Travis singled home the winning run for Connolly in the bottom of the eighth inning. Cam Paradise doubled in the tying runs to force extra innings. Colin D’Ambrosio chipped in with three hits.

Travis pitched four innings of scoreless baseball.

The Cougars (2-5) take on Cape Cod Tech. on Tuesday.

Herald News and Taunton Daily Gazette sports editor Steven Sanchez can be reached at ssanchez@heraldnews.com. You can follow him on Twitter at @Chezsports. Support local journalism by purchasing a digital or print subscription to The Herald News today.
Name_5: Fall 2 All-Scholastics and league All-Stars
Text_5:
Here are the Fall 2 All-Scholastics comprised of athletes in the Boston City League Greater Boston League and South Coast Conference who could not compete during their regular season due to COVID.

Ademide Badmus (Lynn English) boys basketball

Tyrese Baptiste (Everett) football

Amelia Blake (Apponequet) field hockey

Dominek Borden (GNB Voke) boys soccer

Calvin Boudreau (Revere) football

Andrew Cabral (Seekonk) boys cross-country

Rosie Chheang (Lynn English) girls basketball

Jayden Clerveaux (Everett) football

Camryn Crook (Somerset Berkley) field hockey

David Del Rio (Revere) boys swimming

Jair Gomes DePina (O’Bryant) boys soccer

Maura Dorr (Winthrop) girls soccer

Maggie Gallagher (Apponequet) girls cross-country

Aidan Johnson (Somerville) boys hockey

Rachel Kim (Boston Latin) girls soccer

Maya Kirnon (Everett) girls basketball

Samy Lamothe (Everett) football

Kayleigh McDonald (Somerset Berkley) field hockey

John Monexant (Everett) boys basketball

Kim Nguyen (Latin Academy) girls volleyball

Reagan O’Brien (Boston Latin) girls soccer

Katelyn Oliviera (Case) girls soccer

Kostandinos Papajani (Latin Academy)

Markus Pierre (Old Rochester) golf

Lauren Rothwell (Somerset Berkley) field hockey

Louis Rivera Jr. (Lynn English) boys basketball

Josaiah Stewart (Everett) football

Abby Tang (Malden) girls swimming

Ismael Zamor (Everett) football

Catherine Zuffante (Lynn English/Winthrop) girls swimming

ADEMIDE BADMUS

LYNN ENGLISH

The 6-foot-7 senior forward was a force in the paint for the undefeated Bulldogs. Badmus averaged 19 points and 12 rebounds a game surpassing the 1000-point mark in a win over Everett. As a junior Badmus poured in 18 points and 14 rebounds a game in guiding his team to a share of the Div. 1 state title.

TYRESE BAPTISTE

EVERETT

A four-year regular for the Crimson Tide the 5-foot-10 175-pound senior excelled on both sides of the ball. He was a prime shutdown defender while emerging as one of the top receivers for a high-powered offense. He will attend the University of Maine on a football scholarship in the fall.

AMELIA BLAKE

APPONEQUET

The senior left wing was named her team’s Offensive MVP after scoring 19 goals and adding a pair of assists in eight field hockey contests. A four-year starter Blake amassed 50 goals and 15 assists for 65 points. A three-sport athlete and member of the National Honor Society Blake will play college softball at Bridgewater State.

DOMINEK BORDEN

GREATER NEW BEDFORD VOKE

The MVP of the South Coast Conference the senior left wing tallied 13 goals and eight assists. A Bears Award winner in 2018 Borden ended his soccer career with 41 goals and 37 assists. Borden will study physical therapy at Franklin Pierce University.

CALVIN BOUDREAU

REVERE

The senior quarterback threw for 528 yards and four touchdowns while rushing for 210 yards and four touchdowns in four games. For his career Boudreau threw for 2070 yards and ran for 320 amassing 30 touchdowns in 24 games. A Greater Boston League All-Star in basketball Boudreau will play football at Curry College.

ANDREW CABRAL

SEEKONK

One of the premier cross-country runners in the state South Coast Conference MVP Cabral ran a 15:42 at Mine Falls Nashua New Hampshire in the USATF Youth Invitational. A three-time Frank Mooney Male Runner of the Year and South Coast Conference All-Star he also received the Coach’s Award in 2019 given to the athlete who shows the most leadership on and off the track.

ROSIE CHHEANG

LYNN ENGLISH

The junior point guard averaged 12 points four assists and three steals a game for the Bulldogs. A three-year varsity performer Chheang was part of a 2019 Northeastern Conference title team. A member of the Mass. Thundercats AAU program Chheang is an excellent student with a 3.8 GPA.

JAYDEN CLERVEAUX

EVERETT

The junior was one of the top running backs in the Greater Boston League. He rushed for 320 yards and six touchdowns including a three-TD effort against previously unbeaten Revere. Clerveaux showed his ability as a sophomore with a 183-yard effort against Brockton.

CAMRYN CROOK

SOMERSET BERKLEY

The senior midfielder was a scoring machine for the undefeated South Coast Conference field hockey power. The Most Valuable Player in the SCC Crook amassed 42 goals and 21 assists in leading Somerset Berkley to an 11-0 record and the league title. She is the school’s second all-time leading goal scorer (124) and first in assists (153). A member of the National Honor Society Crook will play field hockey and study psychology at Providence College.

DAVID DEL RIO

REVERE

The senior was one of the top swimmers in the Greater Boston League specializing in the 100-backstroke and 200-individual medley holding the school record in those events. A member of the Mystic Swimming Club the UMass-bound Del Rio plans on competing at the AAU Nationals in Texas this summer.

JAIR GOMES DEPINA

BURKE

The sophomore midfielder earned MVP honors after scoring eight goals and adding four assists for 12 points this season. DePina saved his best for last scoring a pair of goals in a 3-1 win over Latin Academy in the Boston City League championship game.

MAURA DORR

WINTHROP

A two-time Northeastern Conference All-Star Dorr scored 17 goals this season giving her a career total of 88. A three-sport standout for the Vikings Dorr was a 1000-point scorer in girls basketball and also surpassed 100 goals in girls lacrosse. Dorr will major in business at the University of Tampa.

MAGGIE GALLAGHER

APPONEQUET

The Most Valuable Player in the SCC the senior helped the Lakers to an undefeated season and the girls cross country title. Gallagher holds the school record in the 2-mile (11:45.99) and has a personal best of 2:32 in the 800-meters and 5:29 in the mile.

AIDAN JOHNSON

SOMERVILLE

The senior defenseman was the MVP of the Greater Boston League after leading the Highlanders to the league title. He posted five goals and 10 assists giving him career totals of 10 goals and 21 assists for 31 points. A member of the National Honor Society with a stellar 4.28 GPA Johnson will attend Bentley College.

RACHEL KIM

BOSTON LATIN

The senior center midfielder made the most of her only season on the soccer team scoring 15 goals and adding 10 assists in 10 games while earning the team’s Best Defensive Player Award. A member of the National Honor Society Kim excelled during the indoor track season. She will play soccer at New York University.

MAYA KIRNON

EVERETT

The senior small forward averaged 18.8 points and 11.5 rebounds a game in leading the Crimson Tide to the Greater Boston League Cup. In the offseason Kirnon plays for Evolution Basketball out of Woburn. A member of the National Honor Society Kirnon will attend Bentley University where she plans to major in computer science with a minor in business.

SAMY LAMOTHE

EVERETT

A three-year starter at safety Lamothe stepped in at quarterback and threw for 341 yards and four touchdowns while rushing for 191 yards and four more scores as Everett went undefeated. Lamothe will play college football at Princeton.

KAYLEIGH MCDONALD

SOMERSET BERKLEY

A mainstay on the defensive front Somerset Berkley never allowed more than two goals in a game in McDonald’s four years on the field hockey team. She scored four goals and added 19 assists as Somerset Berkley went undefeated and extended its winning streak to 55. The Vice President of the National Honor Society McDonald will play field hockey at Tufts University.

JOHN MONEXANT

EVERETT

The junior shooting guard averaged 22.4 points 6.9 rebounds and 1.8 steals a game in leading the Crimson Tide to the finals of the Greater Boston League championship. As a sophomore Monexant earned all-GBL honors for an Everett team which went 17-5 and advanced to the Division 1 North quarterfinals.

KIM NGUYEN

LATIN ACADEMY

The senior outside hitter/libero was the leader of the Boston City League champs. An honor roll student Nguyen spends her offseason competing with Knights Volleyball as well as the MassPats Volleyball Club. She will attend Merrimack College.

REAGAN O’BRIEN

BOSTON LATIN

The junior striker led the Wolfpack in scoring with 24 goals and nine assists as they won the Boston City League title. One of two players to make the varsity team as a freshman O’Brien has career totals of 32 goals and 11 assists for 43 points. A multi-sport athlete O’Brien is a three-time Dual County League All-Star in lacrosse and has verbally committed to play that sport at Johns Hopkins.

KATELYN OLIVEIRA

CASE

The South Coast Conference girls soccer Player of the Year the senior striker tallied 13 goals and three assists in 10 games. In her career Oliveira has 29 goals and 49 assists for 78 points. A team captain and MVP Oliveira will play soccer at American International College where she plans to major in finance.

KOSTANDINOS PAPAJANI

LATIN ACADEMY

The senior midfielder scored 18 goals and added six assists in just nine matches for the Dragons. In his career Papajani amassed 48 goals and 22 assists for 70 points. A two-year captain for Latin Academy Papajani spends his offseason competing for FC Stars. He will continue his soccer career at Marshall University.

MARKUS PIERRE

OLD ROCHESTER

The sophomore was the Most Valuable Golfer in the SCC posting a scoring average of 37. Pierre qualified for and played in the Massachusetts Amateur last summer as a 15-year-old. He also captured the title in the pre-junior division of the Massachusetts Junior Amateur last summer.

LOUIS RIVERA JR.

LYNN ENGLISH

The 6-foot-1 junior guard helped the Bulldogs to an undefeated season and a Greater Boston League title. Rivera averaged 14 points a game and connected on 41 percent of his shots from beyond the arc. In the GBL championship contest against Everett Rivera scored 15 points.

LAUREN ROTHWELL

SOMERSET BERKLEY

The junior midfielder tallied eight goals and 20 assists as Somerset Berkley carted home another SCC field hockey title. Rothwell was a starter on the 2019 state championship team earning league All-Star honors in the process. A high honor roll student Rothwell has already given a verbal commitment to play field hockey at Bryant in 2022.

JOSAIAH STEWART

EVERETT

A top-flight defensive end the 6-foot-2 240-pounder accrued 13 tackles seven for losses 5.5 sacks six quarterback hits and five hurries. For his career the two-time Boston Herald All-Scholastic amassed 12.5 sacks 47 tackles (23 for losses) and 14 quarterback hits. Stewart will play his college football at Coastal Carolina.

ABBY TANG

MALDEN

The captain of her swimming team the junior was the Greater Boston League champion in the 200-individual medley 100-butterfly and 100-freestyle. For her career Tang has qualified for the sectionals and states in both relays events as well as individual competition. Tang is a member of the National Honor Society and Science National Honor Society.

ISMAEL ZAMOR

EVERETT

The junior wide receiver/safety caught eight passes for 250 yards and three touchdowns for the undefeated Crimson Tide. A three-year varsity performer Zamor is a member of the National Honor Society. One of the top recruiting prospects in the East Zamor has already given a verbal commitment to play football at Boston College in 2022.

CATHERINE ZUFFANTE

LYNN ENGLISH/WINTHROP

One of the premier female swimmers in the Greater Boston League Zuffante was named the team’s MVP and also received the John Cahill Award. A year ago Zuffante was a Northeastern Conference All-Star and a sectional qualifier. A high honor roll student throughout her high school career Zuffante will attend the University of Tampa and major in nursing.

BOYS BASKETBALL

GREATER BOSTON LEAGUE

Kanye Wavezwa Lou Rivera Aaron Vizcaino Ademide Badmus (Lynn English); John Monexant Juvens Louis (Everett); Angel Garcia Jayden Thornton (Lynn Classical); Alexei Downie Owen Thompson (Somerville); Aiden Barry (Medford); Ali Alayan (Malden); Calvin Boudreau (Revere)

Brathwaite Nolan Mulcahy (Lynn English); Gio Memeus Matt Bessey Ralph Deus Jr. (Malden); Aidan Barry Alvin Legros Isaiah Blake (Medford); Calvin Boudreau Billy Ginepra John Tran Dillan Day Adetayo Atebbi Alaa Atoui (Revere); Jason Zelaya Matt White Guensley Louis (Somerville)

Kostandinos Papajani Danny Ramirez Erik Van Even (Latin Academy); Marcel Angui John Degazon Merlon Perez (Boston International); Byron Alvarez Jefferson Lopez Victor Reyes (Brighton); Kevin Barbosa Joselito Barandao Jair DePina Gomes (Burke); Mohamud Ahmed Mike Jean Louis Elijah Langley (CASH); Gerardo Escobar Jason Gil Martinez Erick Sanchez (Charlestown); Rogelio Gonzalez Jeremy Ramos Robert Tobar (East Boston); Fabri Hernandez Carlos Riberio (Madison Park); Justin Dacosta Malique Delvalley Dondre Shortts (New Mission); Leandro DePina Ismail Lachmi Ethan Somers (O’Bryant); Santiago Carmona Victor Gonzalez Rafael Sandavol (Snowden); Siloy Blanchet Sieidenlee Edmorin Luis Richard (Tech Boston)
